lead_paragraph: ANOTHER FARE INCREASE Major airlines raised fares again over the weekend by $10 round trip on most routes. The latest round of increases, the sixth this year, was started on Thursday by Delta Air Lines, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Mr. Seaney said that jet fuel prices were nearing $3 a gallon last week, compared with $1.85 a gallon a year ago. Soaring fuel costs will force carriers “to continue to raise airline ticket prices or dramatically cut back capacity,” he said.

headline.main: Major Carriers Raise Fares

abstract: Zinifex, an Australian mining company that specializes in zinc and lead, agreed to be acquired by Oxiana, one of the largest mining companies in Australia, for 6 billion Australian dollars ($5.6 billion). Both companies are based in Melbourne.

abstract: The troubled merger of Genesco/Finish Line has come to an ignominious end. Finish Line, a footwear chain, announced early Tuesday that the parties had agreed to settle all litigation among them relating to their proposed merger and UBS‘s financing of the deal. As part of the settlement, the merger has been dropped. Genesco will get $175 million — $136 million of it from UBS, the rest from Finish Line — as well as 6.5 million shares of Finish Line stock.
lead_paragraph: The troubled merger of Genesco/Finish Line has come to an ignominious end. Finish Line, a footwear chain, announced early Tuesday that the parties had agreed to settle all litigation among them relating to their proposed merger and UBS‘s financing of the deal. As part of the settlement, the merger has been dropped. Genesco will get $175 million — $136 million of it from UBS, the rest from Finish Line — as well as 6.5 million shares of Finish Line stock.

headline.main: Lessons From the Genesco Fight

abstract: Choppy markets, plus some other problems, are wreaking havoc with hedge funds — and denting their reputations as the heavyweights of high finance. Banks have reportedly seized the assets of Peloton Partners, a London-based firm whose bets on mortgage-backed securities went bad. Sailfish Capital Partners, also stung by the credit markets, decided last month to shut down. Accounting problems recently forced D.B. Zwirn to close two of its largest funds.

lead_paragraph: (UPDATED March 7, 9:55 a.m.) This month's jobs report is a great example of how misleading the unemployment rate can be. In February, the economy shed 63,000 jobs, which is a strong indication a recession may be at hand. But the unemployment rate actually fell, to 4.8 percent from 4.9 percent.

abstract: The case of Anthony Pellicano, the onetime sleuth-to-the-stars who is accused of eavesdropping, has a D-list of no-name defendants but big names may be called to testify.
snippet: The case of Anthony Pellicano, the onetime sleuth-to-the-stars who is accused of eavesdropping, has a D-list of no-name defendants but big names may be called to testify.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  More than five years have gone by since a Hollywood reporter who had been menacingly warned off of a story learned that her phones had also been tapped. On Wednesday, Anthony Pellicano, the onetime sleuth-to-the-stars accused of that eavesdropping, will go on trial here on racketeering charges in a case that has alternately seized the entertainment industry’s attention and left it wondering what all the fuss was about.

lead_paragraph: Oil prices reached a record close, surging above $104 after OPEC decided Wednesday to keep its production unchanged. The cartel ignored calls from President Bush to pump more oil into an ailing economy.

headline.main: Oil Hits $104 as OPEC Rebuffs Bush

abstract: BP, the oil company, increased the amount of money it has set aside to settle claims from the deadly 2005 Texas City, Tex., refinery explosion by almost a third, to $2.1 billion.
snippet: BP, the oil company, increased the amount of money it has set aside to settle claims from the deadly 2005 Texas City, Tex., refinery explosion by almost a third, to $2.1 billion.
lead_paragraph: BP, the oil company, increased the amount of money it has set aside to settle claims from the deadly 2005 Texas City, Tex., refinery explosion by almost a third, to $2.1 billion. BP said in December that it had depleted its claims reserve of $1.6 billion. The company used the initial money to settle more than 2,000 cases, a spokeswoman, Wendy Silcock, said. In December, BP said it still had about 1,250 claims, none involving death, after it had spent the $1.6 billion. The company, based in London, raised the set-aside by $500 million. The explosion, on March 23, 2005, killed 15 workers

headline.main: Britain: BP Adds to Claims Fund
headline.print_headline: Britain: Bp Adds To Claims Fund

lead_paragraph: Adecco, a temporary-employment company, said fourth-quarter profit fell 29 percent as hiring slowed in the United States. Net income fell to 150 million euros ($228 million) from 212 million euros a year earlier, when earnings were increased by a tax benefit, Adecco said. Fourth-quarter sales gained 2 percent, to 5.38 billion euros. Revenue from the United States and Canada fell 15 percent, to 752 million euros, in the fourth quarter.

abstract: It’s been almost five years since Conseco emerged from bankruptcy, having been run into the ground by Steve Hilbert, its founder, who became the big man of Indianapolis while being paid hundreds of millions of dollars — and running up huge debts for the company. The local symphony hall was named for him, and the basketball arena bore the Conseco name. After Mr. Hilbert was ousted, the company turned to Gary Wendt, formerly of General Electric, and destroyed his reputation too.

abstract: A federal appeals court has agreed to hear a patent case that may invalidate a controversial class of patents called business method patents, which seek to protect ways of doing business.
snippet: A federal appeals court has agreed to hear a patent case that may invalidate a controversial class of patents called business method patents, which seek to protect ways of doing business.
lead_paragraph: There’s not much love in legal circles for the so-called “business method” patent, an exclusive intellectual property right over a novel way of doing business. Critics of such patents – think Amazon “One Click” or Priceline’s “name your own price” patents – argue that they clog up the United States Patent and Trademark Office, lead to excessive litigation and have little connection to real, physical invention.

headline.main: New Patentable Idea: A Way to Invalidate Vague Patents

lead_paragraph: PicLens makes viewing photos on your computer screen a 3-D experience. You can do a Google search for a particular image, and a wall of images floats across your screen. You pull the stream of photos across the screen as if you were Tom Cruise in “Minority Report.” PicLens, a Web browser add-on, displays photos from Flickr, Facebook, MySpace and Yahoo Images, too. lead_paragraph: When Linda Nazareth, a Canadian economist, emailed me to tell me about her new book, “The Leisure Economy,” the title immediately grabbed me. If there is one thing missing in my life at the moment, it is leisure. So I was eager to find out where this leisure-filled economy existed and how I could get some of it for myself. The only problem was that given the state of my calendar, it took me about four months to get to The Leisure Economy and another few weeks to find the time to interview her.

headline.main: Farewell Time Crunch, Hello Leisure

abstract: Autogrill, the manager of airport restaurants, agreed to buy a BAA unit and the shares it does not own in Aldeasa, the Spanish-based airport retailer, for $1.5 billion, becoming the world’s largest owner of duty-free stores. Autogrill, based in Rozzano, Italy, will pay £546.6 million ($1.1 billion) to purchase World Duty Free Europe from BAA, which is part of Ferrovial of Spain. Autogrill will also acquire the Imperial Tobacco Group’s 49.95 percent stake in Aldeasa for 275 million euros ($423 million). The takeovers will increase Autogrill’s annual revenue by about 1 billion euros, to 6 billion euros. BAA, under fire from airlines and travelers for worsening delays at London’s Heathrow, will use the sale proceeds to reduce £4.1 billion of debt.

abstract: Midsize companies hope to hold business travel spending at current levels.
snippet: Midsize companies hope to hold business travel spending at current levels.
lead_paragraph: KEEP TRAVELING, WORK HARDER A new survey for American Express shows that most midsize companies hope to hold travel spending at current levels this year. But many plan on spending more for on-the-road productivity tools like laptops and mobile phones and other wireless devices. Two-thirds of the companies said they expected to be in a better position on negotiating prices with suppliers, and more than half said they needed to put more effort into monitoring “employee compliance to expense policies,” American Express said. CFO Research Services conducted the survey in November by interviewing more than 400 senior finance executives at midsize companies.

headline.main: Business Travel Miscellany

abstract: European Union antitrust officials raided the offices of several international airlines as part of an investigation into suspected price fixing on scheduled flights between the Europe and Japan. Spokeswomen for Lufthansa of Germany and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, a unit of Air France-KLM, confirmed that their offices in Frankfurt and Amsterdam had been raided and said they were cooperating with the investigation. The European Commission, the European Union’s executive arm, said it and national competition regulators had carried out unannounced inspections at the premises of a number of international airlines. It did not identify the carriers. The commission believes that the companies may have violated its rules on restrictive business practices, officials said, without elaborating.

lead_paragraph: In February, Japan’s consumer confidence dropped to its lowest level in five years as rising oil prices and weak wages sapped households’ spending power. The sentiment index fell to 36.1 last month from 37.5 in January, the Cabinet Office said. It was the lowest level since March 2003, when the unemployment rate was close to a postwar high. The governor of the Bank of Japan, Toshihiko Fukui, above, and his board agreed last month that stagnant wages and deteriorating consumer sentiment “might adversely affect” the nation’s cycle of growth, according to meeting minutes published Wednesday.

abstract: Japan’s lower house of Parliament approved Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda’s candidate to lead the central bank, deepening a political standoff after the upper house rejected the nomination on Wednesday. The lower house, which is controlled by Mr. Fukuda’s Liberal Democratic Party, approved Toshiro Muto, deputy governor of the bank, to lead the Bank of Japan. The standoff increases the possibility the position will go vacant once Toshihiko Fukui’s term expires on Wednesday. The government must propose a new candidate or resubmit the same one after the conflicting votes. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

abstract: The Luxottica Group, one of the world’s biggest makers of eyeglasses, posted its first profit decline in nine quarters on the costs of combining the sports-eyewear maker Oakley with the company’s other divisions. Fourth-quarter profit declined 3.7 percent, to 97 million euros ($151 million) from 100.7 million euros a year earlier, the company said. Luxottica, which is based in Milan, also proposed a 17 percent dividend increase to 49 cents a share. Luxottica, the maker of Ray-Ban sunglasses, paid $2 billion for Oakley in June to cut costs by about 100 million euros a year as profit growth slows and sales weaken in its main United States market. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

abstract: It’s not surprising that Bear Stearns‘s stock plummeted Monday after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didn’t plummet even more.
lead_paragraph: It’s not surprising that Bear Stearns‘s stock plummeted Monday after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didn’t plummet even more.

headline.main: Could Bear Stearns Do Better?

abstract: It’s not surprising that Bear Stearns’s stock plummeted after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didn’t plummet more.
snippet: It’s not surprising that Bear Stearns’s stock plummeted after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didn’t plummet more.
lead_paragraph: It's not surprising that Bear Stearns's stock plummeted Monday after JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy it for just $2 per share. The surprising part is that it didn't plummet even more.  After closing at $30 Friday, Bear's stock hovered at about $4 late Monday morning, suggesting that investors expected to get something more than what JPMorgan has offered. But what? The securities firm was nearly forced to shut its doors because of a severe liquidity crunch. As a company that was preparing a bankruptcy filing over the weekend in case the sale effort failed, Bear seems to be in no position to negotiate.   A number of possibilities come to mind.  Investors may think that JPMorgan will increase its price, if only to avoid being seen as a vulture. Theoretically, Bear's shareholders can vote against the deal, though it would take 12 months to reject it fully under Sunday's merger agreement.  Though the deal price is about $270 million, JPMorgan has said that the true cost of acquiring Bear will be much higher -- as much as $6 billion -- when litigation, severance and other costs are taken into account. So in principle, increasing the per-share price would have a relatively small effect on the overall cost of buying Bear.  Wall Street seems to think JPMorgan is getting a huge bargain: Shares of JPMorgan were up 10 percent Monday, even as other financial firms took a nosedive. Its market capitalization grew by $12 billion, paying for Bear Stearns several times over.  Investors may also be putting hope in the idea that another bidder could step up, such as a private equity firm.  That could be difficult, however. Many analysts think JPMorgan's close ties to Bear, including its role as the go-between for Bear's federally backed bailout loan, have already put it at an advantage over other buyers.  And JPMorgan has another leg up over a rival bidder: Bear has already given JPMorgan the "irrevocable" option to buy its New York headquarters even if the takeover deal falls through, according to the merger agreement, which Bear posted on its Web site Monday.   Finally, Bear shareholders may see another potential source of funds: lawsuits.   A report from Reuters on Monday suggested that law firms were being inundated with calls from angry investors looking for answers -- and, presumably, some payouts for their pain. abstract: HIGHER FARES, AGAIN Another sweeping fare increase by major domestic airlines seemed to be holding on Monday even after United Airlines and Continental Airlines partly rolled back some of their increases over the weekend, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive officer of FareCompare.com. The rise in prices, the fourth this year, was initiated late last week by United Airlines, which raised fares $50 on round-trip routes of over 1,500 miles each way. United’s competitors among the six so-called legacy carriers followed with similar increases over the weekend. Mr. Seaney said that the scattered rollbacks of the increases on some routes appeared to be responses to “normal competitive pressure” rather than a signal of a broad retreat from the increases.

abstract: The Aluminum Corporation of China, the nation’s biggest producer of aluminum, posted a 25 percent fall in second-half profit after prices declined and raw material costs increased. Net income dropped to 3.8 billion yuan in the six months ended Dec. 31, from a revised 5.1 billion yuan a year earlier, the company said. Aluminum prices in China dropped 7.7 percent in the second half from a year earlier after producers increased supplies too quickly. The company said higher prices of raw materials, power and transport would put more pressure on costs this year.

abstract: Lindt & Spruengli, the oldest Swiss chocolate maker, said profit rose 20 percent in 2007 on stronger sales of higher-priced dark chocolate confections. Net income climbed to 250.5 million Swiss francs ($255 million) from 209 million francs in 2006, the company said. “Thanks to numerous innovations and targeted marketing activities, the group outpaced the growth of the overall chocolate market and gained substantial new market share,” the company said. Lindt, based in Kilchberg, said in January that sales increased 14 percent, to 2.95 billion francs, last year.

lead_paragraph: Investigators took documents from the headquarters of BP’s joint venture here, TNK-BP, which has had rocky relations with the Kremlin. The Russian ministry of interior is investigating a criminal case related to Sidanko, an oil company that merged with TNK-BP when BP bought into the venture in 2003, according to Irina V. Dudukina, a spokeswoman for the ministry’s investigative committee. A spokeswoman for TNK-BP declined to comment. The venture is important for BP, based in London, because it accounts for about a quarter of the company’s total production worldwide.

headline.main: Russia: Raid at Joint Oil Venture

lead_paragraph: Cadbury Schweppes, the candy maker, has set the terms of its soda unit’s planned spinoff. Cadbury said that shareholders would receive 64 shares of the Cadbury confectionery unit and 12 shares of the Dr Pepper Snapple Group for every 100 Cadbury Schweppes shares they hold when the split occurs in May. The company has said stock in Dr Pepper Snapple should start trading on May 7, in line with its plan to complete the spinoff by the end of the second quarter.

snippet: A lawyer-turned-Baptist minister/stand-up comic uses humor to connect with congregants.
lead_paragraph: Susan Sparks sits at the intersection of a bevy of career trends. First, she needs a rather long string of words to describe what she does, usually beginning with something like “I’m a lawyer-turned-Baptist preacher who moonlights as a stand-up comic.” As a preacher/comic, she’s a slash and a hyphenate. As someone who uses her skills as a lawyer in her current career — her church relies on her for the occasional legal perspective on everything from property to contracts — she leads what Penelope Trunk calls a “braided career.”

abstract: The rise of companies that want to get data from Internet service providers in order to track the Web surfing of users is no doubt going to raise battles about online privacy to a new height.
snippet: The rise of companies that want to get data from Internet service providers in order to track the Web surfing of users is no doubt going to raise battles about online privacy to a new height.
lead_paragraph: All of the outrage over privacy on the Internet is nothing compared to what may be coming. For years, Web companies have been trying to gather shreds of information about users in order to show them ads for things they are most likely to buy. These schemes have been accelerated over the last year, as the big Web companies like AOL, Microsoft and Yahoo have been trying to combine information they gather on their own sites with data about users gathered from networks that place ads on other sites.

headline.main: The Mother of All Privacy Battles

abstract: Real estate bubbles have burst before, without bringing such trouble to the financial system. What is distinctive today is the drying up of market liquidity.
snippet: Real estate bubbles have burst before, without bringing such trouble to the financial system. What is distinctive today is the drying up of market liquidity.
lead_paragraph: REAL estate bubbles have burst before, without bringing such trouble to the financial system. What is distinctive today is the drying up of market liquidity  the inability to buy and sell financial assets  caused by a lack of good information about asset values. The American economy is suffering from an old conundrum: that liquidity is there when you don’t need it, but missing when you do. The results have been a form of financial gridlock.

abstract: An Australian Internet provider said its attempts to provide wireless service through a technology called WiMax have failed. The signals simply don’t travel far enough and have too many delays, it said.

lead_paragraph: The WiMax technology has been put forward as a way to shake up not one, but two oligopolies. It is a method of wirelessly transmitting data over long distances. It can be used in place of home broadband service from the phone or cable company. And it may also provide an alternative to cellphone networks for on-the-go Internet access. Intel has been a main backer.

headline.main: WiMax Gets Less-Than-Max Grades in Australia

abstract: Pluspetrol, the Argentine energy company, has reopened an oil field in Peru’s northeastern Amazon region as violent clashes between police and members of the local indigenous community subsided. The company said Block 1-AB in the Loreto department was operating normally. Pluspetrol had suspended operations at Block 1-AB, which accounts for most of Peru’s oil output, on Thursday after protesters demanding higher salaries for local Pluspetrol workers stormed the installations. The clashes with police grew violent, and one officer was killed and five were wounded.
lead_paragraph: Pluspetrol, the Argentine energy company, has reopened an oil field in Peru’s northeastern Amazon region as violent clashes between police and members of the local indigenous community subsided. The clashes with police grew violent, and one officer was killed and five were wounded.

snippet: AbitibiBowater, North America’s largest newsprint maker, agreed to sell $350 million of convertible bonds to Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd.
lead_paragraph: AbitibiBowater, North America’s largest newsprint maker, agreed to sell $350 million of convertible bonds to Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. to help avoid defaulting on debt due in the second quarter. The sale is part of a previously announced $1.4 billion refinancing plan. AbitibiBowater, based in Montreal, has struggled to win creditor support to extend the maturity of its debt amid turmoil in credit markets and falling North American consumption of newsprint.

headline.main: Canada: Paper Maker to Sell Bond
headline.print_headline: Canada: Paper Maker to Sell Bond

abstract: The Bank of Israel cut the April interest rate by 50 basis points, to 3.25 percent, citing the probability of a world economic slowdown.
snippet: The Bank of Israel cut the April interest rate by 50 basis points, to 3.25 percent, citing the probability of a world economic slowdown.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of Israel cut the April interest rate by 50 basis points, to 3.25 percent, citing the probability of a world economic slowdown, which would decrease inflationary pressures. Taking this cut into consideration, the central bank expects inflation over the next 12 months to be 2.7 percent, within the government’s target range for annual inflation of 1 to 3 percent. The rate cut is the bank’s second consecutive 50-basis-point monthly reduction. In late February, it cut the rate to 3.75 percent for March.

headline.main: Israel: Central Bank Cuts Rate
headline.print_headline: Israel: Central Bank Cuts Rate

abstract: PREMIUM AIR TRAVEL SAGS Premium traffic, which had been increasing robustly around the world in recent years, “is now slowing sharply,” said the International Air Transport Association, noting that the number of passengers traveling globally in first- and business-class seats “barely grew” in January compared with January 2007. Premium traffic on the lucrative trans-Atlantic routes grew 5.6 percent in 2007, and was 2.6 percent higher in January compared with January 2007. But that represented slowing compared with December, when trans-Atlantic premium traffic rose 5.7 percent over December 2006. Premium traffic to and from the Middle East continued to grow unabated, with a 20.6 percent increase last year, the international airline trade group said. Continental Airlines has announced a sharp reduction in 60-day advance-purchase business-class fares to Europe for the summer. Here’s a sample round-trip fare: Newark-London Heathrow, $1,798 plus taxes and fees.

Premium traffic on the lucrative trans-Atlantic routes grew 5.6 percent in 2007, and was 2.6 percent higher in January compared with January 2007. But that represented slowing compared with December, when trans-Atlantic premium traffic rose 5.7 percent over December 2006. Premium traffic to and from the Middle East continued to grow unabated, with a 20.6 percent increase last year, the international airline trade group said. Continental Airlines has announced a sharp reduction in 60-day advance-purchase business-class fares to Europe for the summer. Here’s a sample round-trip fare: Newark-London Heathrow, $1,798 plus taxes and fees.

abstract: Japan’s trade surplus rose 0.9 percent in February from a year earlier, to 970 billion yen ($9.69 billion), in the first increase in four months, the Finance Ministry said. The trade surplus with the United States fell 13.3 percent, to 696.9 billion yen ($6.96 billion). The surplus with Asian nations including China jumped 104.8 percent, to 922.2 billion yen ($9.22 billion).
snippet: Japan’s trade surplus rose 0.9 percent in February from a year earlier, to 970 billion yen ($9.69 billion), in the first increase in four months, the Finance Ministry said. The trade surplus with the United States fell 13.3 percent, to 696.9 billi...
lead_paragraph: Japan’s trade surplus rose 0.9 percent in February from a year earlier, to 970 billion yen ($9.69 billion), in the first increase in four months, the Finance Ministry said. The trade surplus with the United States fell 13.3 percent, to 696.9 billion yen ($6.96 billion). The surplus with Asian nations including China jumped 104.8 percent, to 922.2 billion yen ($9.22 billion).

abstract: A small business expert advises people who want to take the leap and become entrepreneurs to follow the ancient Greek maxim: know thyself.
snippet: A small business expert advises people who want to take the leap and become entrepreneurs to follow the ancient Greek maxim: know thyself.
lead_paragraph: Terry Corbell, a management consultant, has some advice for all the readers who responded to an invitation I made last month to send him questions about running a business. Make a list of your weaknesses, he told those who asked how to get started. Because so many e-mail messages poured in, Mr. Corbell, the author of a column called The Biz Coach that appears on the Web sites of an all-news radio and television station in Seattle, chose to address in this column the ones that reflected three major entrepreneurial dilemmas: how to take the leap into the small business world, how to market your product and, for retail ventures, how to find the best location.

headline.main: Advice on Taking an Entrepreneurial Leap

While it is shameful that adequate and affordable health insurance is so difficult to find that it affects people’s career choices, I did find one bright light in researching this subject. abstract: Canadian communications regulators approved the 51.7 billion Canadian dollar ($50.9 billion) buyout of BCE, the country’s biggest phone provider, and set conditions that require the carrier to remain Canadian controlled. One of the six criteria requires Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan to appoint six directors, instead of the five proposed. The pension plan and its United States partners agreed to modify the original deal to appease the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission, which had expressed concerns that BCE might end up being controlled by United States investors. That proposal did not go far enough, the agency said in its decision. Deborah Allan, a spokeswoman for the pension plan, said the pension fund was reviewing the conditions and had no further comment.

The pension plan and its United States partners agreed to modify the original deal to appease the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission, which had expressed concerns that BCE might end up being controlled by United States investors. That proposal did not go far enough, the agency said in its decision. Deborah Allan, a spokeswoman for the pension plan, said the pension fund was reviewing the conditions and had no further comment.

abstract: The Bush administration is proposing the broadest overhaul of Wall Street regulation since the Great Depression, in effect allowing it to send SWAT teams into any corner of the industry or any institution that might pose a risk to the overall system.
